[[Nishan-e-Imtiaz]] (2012) | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | spouse = }} '''Munir Ahmad Khan''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|منير احمد خان}}}}; b. 20 May 1926 – 22 April 1999; [[Nishan-e-Imtiaz|''NI'']] [[Hilal-e-Imtiaz|''HI'']]), was a [[People of Pakistan|Pakistani]] [[nuclear engineer]] and a [[Nuclear Physics|nuclear physicist]],{{harvnb|Ali|2012|pp=1965–1967}}{{Cite news | last =(NYT) | first =The New York Times | title =Obituary: Munir Khan Dies; Developed Pakistan Bomb Project. | page =1 | newspaper =The New York Times | location =Paris | date =24 April 1999 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/24/news/24iht-obit.2.t_16.html }}{{cite web|last=Editorial|title=Mr. Munir Ahmad Khan (1926–1999)|url=http://nustscienceblog.wordpress.com/tag/dr-munir-ahmad-khan/|website=Nust Science Society|publisher=The NUST science Society|accessdate=28 October 2012|format=tag|date=17 August 2012}} who served as the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission#Following is the list of PAEC chairmen|chairman]] of the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] (PAEC) from 1972 to 1991. He is credited among the persons who are called as "father of the Pakistan's [[Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program|atomic bomb project]]",{{harvnb|Ali|2012|pp=1966}} for their role in Pakistan's integrated{{clarify|date=June 2015}} atomic bomb project— the clandestine [[Cold War (1979–1985)|Cold war]]{{dubious|date=June 2015}} program. Khan was technical director of the programme to develop [[nuclear weapons]], which led to the [[Chagai-I]] [[nuclear testing]] in May 1998 in [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]].{{cite web | last =(IISS) | first =International Institute for Strategic Studies|authorlink =International Institute for Strategic Studies| title =Bhutto was father of Pakistan's Atom Bomb Programme| website = | publisher =International Institute for Strategic Studies| year =2006 | url =http://www.iiss.org/whats-new/iiss-in-the-press/press-coverage-2007/may-2007/bhutto-was-father-of-pakistani-bomb/?locale=en| doi = | accessdate =2011 }}Babar, Farhatullah, "Munir Will Remain Immortal in country's nuclear history," The Nation newspaper (Islamabad) 2 June 1999. A technical adviser to the newly created [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|PAEC]] since 1958, Khan used that position in [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]] for lobbying for country's industrial [[Nuclear power in Pakistan|nuclear power]] development. A proponent of an [[Nuclear arms race#India and Pakistan|arm race]] with [[India]], he remained associated with his country's various strategic science projects for more than four decades until his death in 1999. After securing the chairmanship of the [[Board of Governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency|Board of Governors]] of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]] from 1986–87, he made a strong case for Pakistan's peaceful development on [[Nuclear energy in Pakistan|nuclear energy]]. Serving until 1999 as [[Visiting scholar|visiting professor]] of [[physics]] at the [[Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences|Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences]] in [[Islamabad]], he was instrumental in establishing the [[International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics and Contemporary Needs]]. He also made critical contributions on the development of the nuclear [[nuclear fuel cycle|fuel cycle]] including setting up the [[Khushab Nuclear Complex|plutonium program]] as well as the establishment of [[Nuclear reprocessing|reprocessing]] plants.Haris N. Khan, "Pakistan's Nuclear Development: Setting the Record Straight," Defence Journal, August 2010 In 1986, he entered into a comprehensive civil nuclear energy agreement with [[People's Republic of China|China]], which led the established the [[Chashma Nuclear Power Plant#Unit 1|C-1]] reactor at the [[Chashma Nuclear Power Plant]]. ==Youth and early life== Munir Ahmad Khan was born in [[Kasur]], [[Punjab Province (British India)|Punjab]], [[British Indian Empire]] into a [[Kakazai]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1365402|title=The history of Lahore’s Kakayzais|last=Sheikh|first=Majid|date=2017-10-22|work=DAWN.COM|access-date=2018-02-28|language=en-US}} Muslim family on 20 May 1926.{{cite book|last1=Bhattacharya|first1=Samir|title=Nothing But! All Is Fair in Love and War|date=2014|publisher=Partridge Pub|isbn=978-1482817324}} Educated from [[Lahore]], he enrolled at the [[Government College University, Lahore|Government College University]] in 1942 and graduated with [[Double degree|double]] [[Bachelor of Science|bachelors]] in [[physics]] and [[mathematics]] at the prestigious [[Government College University, Lahore|Government College University]] in 1946 as a contemporary of the [[List of Nobel laureates in Physics|Nobel Laureate]] Professor [[Abdus Salam]].{{cite web|last1=Editorial|title=Dr. Munir Ahmad Khan (1926–1999)|url=https://nustscienceblog.wordpress.com/2012/08/17/dr-munir-ahmad-khan-1926-1999/|accessdate=21 January 2015}} He enrolled at the [[University of the Punjab|Punjab University]] in 1949 and began studying the [[electrical engineering]]; he graduated in 1951 with a [[Bachelor of Science|bachelors]] in [[electrical engineering]] with an academic [[Honors student|Roll of Honour]].{{cite web|last=Asim|first=Khalid Mahmood|title=Dr. Munir Ahmed Khan [1926–1999]|url=http://www.nazariapak.info/Famous-Pakistani/Scientists.php|website=http://www.nazariapak.info/|publisher=Nazaria-e-Pakistan Trust|accessdate=21 January 2015|format=php}} In 1951, Khan joined the teaching faculty at the [[University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore|University of Engineering and Technology]] (UET), providing instruction in undergraduate mathematics. After winning the [[Fulbright Scholarship]], Khan went to the [[United States]] and in 1952 completed a [[Master of Science]] in [[electrical engineering]] at [[North Carolina State University]].Dr.M.S. Jillani, "Man of Honor," The News (Islamabad), 3 June 1999."Munir Khan Passes Away," Business Recorder, 23 April 1999. ===Studies in the United States=== In the United States, Khan gradually lost interest in [[electrical engineering]] and began studies in advanced physics. In 1953, he moved to [[Chicago]] and began taking interests in [[thermodynamics]] and began post-graduate work on [[Kinetic theory of gases|kinetic theory]] of gases at the [[Illinois Institute of Technology]] which continued until 1956 during which time he also received preliminary training in atomic energy. By 1956, he was selected for the [[Atoms for Peace]] initiatives and participated in the Nuclear Engineering training program at the [[North Carolina State University]] while continued his research on nuclear power sources at the [[Argonne National Laboratory]], Illinois.{{cite web | last =Ahmad | first =Ishtiaq | authorlink = | title =Remembering Munir Ahmad Khan | publisher =Ishtiaq Ahmad | date = 21 April 2006 | url =http://www.ishtiaqahmad.com/item_display.aspx?listing_id=562&listing_type=1 | doi = | accessdate =2011 }}20 Years VIC (1979–1999), ECHO, Journal of the IAEA Staff- No. 202, pp. 24–25 In 1957, he completed his program and earned a [[Master of Science]] in [[nuclear engineering]]. He was part of the third batch of [[North Carolina State University|NCSU]]'s graduates who had specialized in reactor physics and nuclear engineering. The major part of his research in [[nuclear reactor]]s was carried out at the [[Argonne National Laboratory]] operated by the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|USAEC]] and the [[University of Chicago]], the site of the first self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction in 1942. ==Early professional work== While at the [[Illinois Institute of Technology]], Khan was awarded [[Sigma Xi|Sigma-Xi]] fellowship in recognition of his research work. His early professional work was with the [[Wisconsin]]-based [[Allis-Chalmers]] where he worked as a [[Systems engineering|system engineer]] for a short time before joining the [[Commonwealth Edison]] in [[Chicago]]. It was during his work with [[Allis-Chalmers]] that Khan began taking interests in [[nuclear physics]] due to [[Allis-Chalmers|company's]] background on [[nuclear technology]]. During [[World War II]], the [[Allis-Chalmers]] was a sub-contractor and manufacturer of pumps and equipment for the ''[[K-25]]'' [[gaseous diffusion]] [[uranium enrichment]] plant, at [[Oak Ridge, Tennessee]] for the [[Manhattan Project]]. At [[Commonwealth Edison]], Khan's work took place working on a project on building the [[Experimental Breeder Reactor I|EBR-I]]– the world's first commercial nuclear power plant. All of early professional work took involved working in nuclear project, which lead Khan to enrolled at the nuclear engineering program of the [[North Carolina State University|NCSU]]Munir Ahmad Khan Interview with Urdu Digest, October 1981. In 1957, Khan served as a Resident Research Associate in the [[Nuclear Engineering]] Division of the Argonne National Laboratory where he worked as a reactor design engineer on "Modifications of [[Chicago Pile 5|CP-5]] reactor." He then served in the Reactor Division of the American Machine Foundry Company, AMF Atomics, where he worked on the "Thermodynamic Design of Japan Research Reactor-2" till 1958. ===International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)=== After graduating in [[nuclear engineering]] from the [[United States]], Khan was offered to join the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) in 1958, becoming a staff member in Professional Grade P-5. Eventually, he joined the IAEA's Nuclear power division and was the first Asian member from any [[developing country]] who was appointed at a senior technical position in the IAEA. In 1958, Khan joined the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission]] (PAEC) technical branch, serving at the advisory board. At IAEA, he earned the nickname as the "''Reactor Khan'', and began assisting Pakistan at IAEA on nuclear issues. By 1961, he was a senior officer responsible for [[Nuclear Reactor Technology|reactor technology]] at the Reactor Division of the IAEA, and from 1968, Khan was now heading the IAEA's Reactor Division till 1972. His major responsibilities as head of IAEA's Reactor Division included developing and implementing programs in the field of research in [[Utilization factor|reactor utilization]] in nuclear centers, technical and economic assessment of [[nuclear power]] reactors, world survey of nuclear [[power plants]] for developing countries, construction and operating experience with nuclear stations, [[fast breeder reactor]]s and [[combined heat and power|nuclear desalination]].{{Cite journal | last = IAEA | first =International Atomic Energy Agency | authorlink =International Atomic Energy Agency | title =Research and Isotopes | journal =IAEA Journal of Science | volume = | issue = | pages =22–23 | date =17–21 December 1962 | url =http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Magazines/Bulletin/Bull052/05205002024.pdf | jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate =1 September 2009}} As a senior IAEA staff member, Khan also organized more than 20 international technical and scientific conferences and seminars on [[heavy water]] reactors, advanced [[Gas Cooled Reactor]]s, [[Plutonium uranium extraction|plutonium utilisation]], performance of nuclear power plants, problems and prospects of introducing nuclear power in developing countries, Small and Medium Power Reactors{{Cite journal | last = IAEA | first =International Atomic Energy Agency | authorlink =International Atomic Energy Agency | title =Prospects For Small and Medium Power Nuclear Reactors: The cost of nuclear power | journal = | volume = | issue = | pages =3–7 | publisher =Directorate for IAEA Press Release | location =Vienna, Austria | date =5–6 September 1960 | url =http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Magazines/Bulletin/Bull031/03104700308.pdf | jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate =1 September 2009}} and coordination of programs for research in Theoretical Estimation of Uranium Depletion and Plutonium build-up in Power Reactors in the [[United States]], [[Soviet Union]], [[United Kingdom]], [[France]] and [[Canada]]. In 1961, he prepared a technical feasibility report on behalf of the IAEA on Small Power Reactor projects of the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission]].{{Cite journal | last =Khan | first =Munir Ahmad | authorlink =International Atomic Energy Agency |author2=P. Augustine | title =Small Power Reactor Projects of USAEC | journal =(Reactor Technology) | volume = | issue = | pages =3–7 | date =September 1961 | url = | jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate =}} While at the IAEA, Munir Khan also served as Scientific Secretary to the Third and Fourth [[United Nations|UN]] [[List of international environmental agreements|International Geneva Conferences on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy]] in 1964 and 1971 respectively.{{cite web | title =Munir Ahmad Khan (1927–1999) | url =http://portal.ictp.it/pio/words/news/1999/news_1999_May_03.news/ | date =3 May 1999 | accessdate = 6 August 2009}} He also served as Chairman of the IAEA Board of Governors from 1986–87 and was the leader of Pakistan's delegations to 19 IAEA General Conferences from 1972–90. He also served as a Member of the IAEA Board of Governors for 12 years.{{Cite journal | last =Khan | first =Munir Ahmad | authorlink =International Atomic Energy Agency |author2=P. Augustine | title =In Memorian: Munir Ahmad Khan | journal =IAEA Bulletin | volume = | issue = | pages =3–10 | date =14 February 2009 | url =http://www.iaea.org/Publications/Magazines/Bulletin/Bull412/article11.pdf | jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate =1 September 1961}} ===International Centre for Theoretical Physics=== {{Main|International Centre for Theoretical Physics|Abdus Salam|Theoretical physics}} Since the 1940s, Munir Khan and the [[List of Nobel laureates in Physics|Nobel Laureate]] in [[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]], Professor [[Abdus Salam]] were associates who studied Physics and Mathematics together at Government College, Lahore.{{Cite journal | last =Hamende | first =A.M. | authorlink = |author2=Munir Ahmad Khan | title =Tribute to Abdus Salam: §A Long Friendship with Abdus Salam | journal =Unesco Science Journal | volume =1 | issue =1 | pages =101–159 | date =22 November 1997 | url =http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0011/001190/119078Eb.pdf | jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate =2011 }} Khan recognised the importance of [[Theoretical physics]], and had studied its "real world" applications that related to the field of nuclear engineering, whilst trying to solve the reactor physics problems. During 1967, he and Salam prepared a proposal for setting up a nuclear fuel and plutonium reprocessing plant in Pakistan, which was deferred by President Field Marshal [[Ayub Khan (Field Marshal)|Ayub Khan]] on [[economic]] grounds.Munir Ahmad Khan, "''Salam Passes into History''", The News (Islamabad), 24 November 1996. In fact, Khan was the first person at the IAEA who was consulted by Abdus Salam in September 1960 about the establishment of the [[International Centre for Theoretical Physics]] (ICTP), [[Trieste]].http://users.ictp.it/~sci_info/News_from_ICTP/News_89/monitor.html. Retrieved 6 August 2009. Khan played a very important role in the establishment of the ICTP by way of securing the support of the IAEA the cause.{{cite book|last=Gill|first=Mohammad Akram|title=Modernity and the Muslim world|year=2006|publisher=AuthorHouse|location=Bloomington, IN|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Fbw3m4Ay45cC&pg=PA110&lpg=PA110&dq=Munir+Ahmad+Khan+ICTP#v=onepage&q=Munir%20Ahmad%20Khan%20ICTP&f=false|chapter=Founder of the International Center for Theoretical Physics (ICTP)|isbn=978-1-4259-5671-4}} According to Khan, Nobel laureate [[Isidor Isaac Rabi|Isidor Rabi]] and [[Homi J. Bhabha|Homi Bhabha]], members of the scientific advisory committee of IAEA, [[Unanimous decision|unanimously]] opposed the establishment of ICTP. Privately, Bhabha wanted to establish the ICTP in Mumbai, but Salam refused. Therefore, Khan teamed up with Salam and established the ICTP in Italy, despite many initiatives taken against it. Following the same tradition, in 1976, Abdus Salam and Munir Khan established the [[International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics|Annual international Nathiagali Summer College on Theoretical Physics and Contemporary Needs in Pakistan]] where the first conference was held on Theoretical physics and [[Quantum Mechanics]] in 1976. Munir Khan took special interest in holding the first INSC in 1976 and since then it has evolved into an annual event and an institution for interaction between Nobel Laureates and scientists from the developing world. He invited hundreds of scientists from all over the world to come to Pakistan and interact with Pakistani scientists.http://www.thenucleuspak.org.pk/nucleus/pdf%20Special%20Issue%20Nucleus%2042(1-4)/International%20Nathiagali%20Summer%20College%20(ms616).pdf./ In December 1972, Abdus Salam directed two Pakistani [[theoretical physicists]], [[Riazuddin (physicist)|Riazuddin]] and [[Masud Ahmad]], who were working under him at the ICTP, to report to Munir Khan on their return to Pakistan where they formed the "Theoretical Physics Group" (TPG) in PAEC. This group would go on to develop the theoretical design of Pakistan's nuclear weapons.Shahid-ur-Rahman Khan, ''Long Road to Chaghi'' (Islamabad: Print Wise Publications, 1999), pp. 38–39. On August 1996, Khan met Abdus Salam in [[Oxford]]. Khan wrote: {{quote|text=My last meeting with Abdus Salam was only three months ago. His disease had taken its toll and he was unable to talk. Yet he understood what was said. I told him about the celebration held in Pakistan on his seventieth birthday. He kept staring at me. He had risen above praise. As I rose to leave he pressed my hand to express his feelings as if he wanted to thank everyone who had said kind words about him. Now he has returned home finally, to rest in peace for ever in the soil that he loved so much. May be in the years to come we will rise above our prejudice and own him and give him, after his death, what we could not when he was alive... |sign=Munir Ahmad Khan paying tribute to Abdus Salam|source=}} Munir Khan's efforts at lobbying for the up-gradation and strengthening of the [[Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences]] (PIEAS), which he had established in 1976 as Pakistan's premier institute for physics and engineering, resulted in PIEAS being awarded university status in 1997 as a full-fledged science research institute status by the government in 2000, culminating as the Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences (PIEAS).http://www.pieas.edu.pk/about/genesis.php Munir Khan remained associated with the [[Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences|PIEAS]] as the [[associate professor]] of [[physics]], a passion that remained entire his life, and was instrumental in scientific competition in the PIEAS between students and professors. ==Zulifikar Ali Bhutto's trusted aide== {{Main|Zulfikar Ali Bhutto#Father of the Nuclear weapons program}} Munir Ahmad Khan became increasingly concerned about politics and international affairs after Pakistan's [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|1965 war]] with India.{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=95–99}} Although, he did not personally know Bhutto at the time though he had seen Bhutto's role in PAEC in 1958 as [[Ministry of Water and Power (Pakistan)|Energy Minister]]. Khan had his first meeting with Bhutto in October 1965 in [[Vienna]] and asked him to inform the [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan government]] about the quick advancement and advanced status of the [[Indian nuclear programme]]; many options were drawn out by Munir Khan to Bhutto for Pakistan to acquire its own [[Capability (systems engineering)|nuclear deterrence capability]].{{harvnb|Khan|2012|pp=105–108}} As Bhutto sensed the importance of the issue, he arranged Munir's private meeting with [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Ayub Khan (Field Marshal)|Ayub Khan]] on 11 December 1965, at the [[Dorchester Hotel]] in [[London]].{{harvnb|Khan|2012|pp=110–111}} Without wasting time, Munir Khan asked President Ayub Khan to pursue the [[nuclear deterrent]] against the India's armed [[India and weapons of mass destruction|nuclear threat]].{{harvnb|Khan|2012|pp=112–113}} While President Ayub Khan patiently listened to Munir Khan's offer, which according to Munir Khan, was available free of safeguards and at an affordable cost from international supplier states, the President swiftly dismissed the offer since he believed that Pakistan "was too poor to spend" so much money and ended the meeting that if needed, Pakistan would "somehow buy it off the shelf". Although the meeting was not successful as expected, Bhutto and Munir Khan vowed to deter the Indian nuclear threat with Bhutto quoting: "''Don't worry. Our turn will come''".{{cite web|last=Baber|first=Farhatullah|title=Bhutto's Footprints on Nuclear Pakistan|url=http://sixhour.com/bhutto_footprints_on%20nuclear_pakistan.htm|publisher=Pakistan Peoples Party's archives|accessdate=13 October 2012|date=4 April 2006}} This was the beginning of their association, and Munir Khan increasingly became involved with politics and the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP). Finally, the goal of making Pakistan a [[Nuclear power in Pakistan|nuclear power]] saw its first milestone when country's first commercial [[Karachi Nuclear Power Plant|nuclear power plant]] was inaugurated in [[Karachi]] 28 November 1972. There, Prime Minister Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto and Munir Khan recalled their past association and similarity of views about developing nuclear capability for Pakistan. While addressing the Munir Ahmad Khan, Bhutto said: {{cquote|''"Since 1965, I have been in close touch with you (Chairman PAEC) and we have had many occasions to discuss how atomic energy can help in the development of our country. That is why soon after assuming this office, I not only placed the Atomic Energy Commission under my direct control, but asked you to return to the country and serve the nation. I am glad that the Atomic Energy Commission is on the move with a well-defined and broad-based programme for the future. I believe that Pakistan's survival lies in using nuclear research, nuclear technology, and nuclear power for the betterment of its people. The Government will give the fullest support to the Programme of the Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission and this country will make the necessary resources available to bring the promise of atomic energy to the people of Pakistan at the earliest possible time".''S.K. Pasha, "Solar Energy and the Guests at KANUPP Opening", Morning News (Karachi), November 29, 1972.}} In his inaugural address, the Munir Ahmad Khan addressed the Prime Minister of Pakistan Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto and stated: {{cquote|''"I remember the day in October, 1965 when I had the opportunity of discussing with you the tremendous potential which atomic energy had and the role it could play in the development of our country. You not only listened but insisted that I present my view to higher-ups. I went. But my pleadings made no impact and I was dubbed as another mad man who thought like Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto. But the times have changed and so has the destiny of our country".''}} Throughout the development of the atomic bomb in the 1970s and 80s, Munir Khan continued his left-wing associations with the Peoples Party even after Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto was [[Operation Fair Play|overthrown]] in a coup led by [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia-ul-Haq]] who shifted in Bhutto in the [[Adiala Jail]].{{harvnb|Rehman|1998|pp=55–66}} Bhutto continued to send messages to Munir Ahmad Khan inquiring about the progress of various projects of the atomic bomb project when the Chairman of PAEC would visit the former Prime Minister of Pakistan in jail on the pretext of delivering oranges and vitamins to update him on the status of the nuclear weapons program.{{harvnb|Rehman|1998|pp=113–114}} [[Benazir Bhutto|Benazir]] and [[Murtaza Bhutto]] were instructed by her father to have keep the contacts with Munir Ahmad Khan.In 1977, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto instructed his children, Benazir and Murtaza, to keep in touch with the Chairman of PAEC. In 1978, Munir Khan told Benazir and Murtaza that the designing process of the bomb was completed and, Zulfikar Bhutto expected the nuclear test in August 1978. Munir Khan then told Murtaza and Benazir that the tests are moved to December 1978, but delayed indefinitely due to political and diplomatic considerations of the country. Benazir Bhutto, however, continued her ties with Munir Khan and awarded him the Hilal-i-Imtiaz in 1989 for his services to Pakistan's nuclear program in developing nuclear fuel cycle technology for the country.http://www.nti.org/media/pdfs/pakistan_nuclear.pdf?_=1316466791 ==Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC)== {{Main|Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program}} On 16 December 1971, Pakistan ultimately called out for a [[ceasefire]] to end the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|war]] with [[India]] and unconditionally [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|surrendered]] to India, which culminated with the [[East Pakistan|East-Pakistan]] becoming the independent [[Bangladesh]].{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=38}} On 20 January 1972, [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] chaired a winter session at [[Multan]] which was arranged and held by [[Abdus Salam]] and authorized the [[Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction|crash program]] to develop an [[atomic bomb]] for sake of a "national survival".{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=39–40}} [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] invited Khan to take over the work on the [[Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction|crash program]], a task that Khan threw himself into with full vigor.{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=40–41}} In spite of having been unknown to many senior scientists, Khan busied himself on development of the [[Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction|crash program]], assisting in [[fast neutron calculations]].{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=42}} The fact that Khan was not a [[Doctoral studies|doctorate holder]], his extensive experience as [[nuclear engineer]] and then director of [[Nuclear reactor physics|reactor physics]] division at [[IAEA]], enabled him to direct senior scientists to work under him on nuclear projects.{{cite web|last1=Mehmud|first1=Salim|title=Memoirs of Salim Mehmud|url=http://pakdef.org/munir-ahmad-khan-memorial-reference/|website=http://pakdef.org/|publisher=Salim Mehmud on Munir Khan's work|accessdate=21 January 2015}} In a short time, he impressed the conservatively-aligned [[Pakistan Military|military]] by the breadth of his knowledge and his unparallel singular grasp in [[engineering]], [[Military logistics|ordnance]], [[metallurgy]], [[chemistry]] and interdisciplinary projects that would differs the [[physics]].{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=42–43}} A detailed framework was established and submitted to [[Prime Minister's Secretariat (Pakistan)|Prime Minister's Secretariat]] which envisioned the infrastructure establishment of numerous manufacturing plants and facilities needed to master the complete [[nuclear fuel cycle]]. On November 1972, he and [[Abdus Salam|Salam]] assisted [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto|Bhutto]] in inaugurating country's first 137[[Megawatt|MWe]] commercial [[nuclear power plant]], [[KANUPP|KANUPP-I]]. On December 1972, Khan joined [[Abdus Salam|Salam]] to initiate the work on [[fast neutron calculations]] necessary for the physics mechanism for the [[atomic bomb]]s.{{cite book|last=Rehman|first=Shahidur|title=Long Road to Chagai:§ The Theoretical Physics Group: a cue to Manhattan Project?|year=1999|publisher=Shahid-ur-Rehman, 1999; Printwise Publications|location=Islamabad, Oxford|isbn=978-969-8500-00-9|page=157|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sNMgAQAAIAAJ&q=Munir+Ahmad+Khan&dq=long+road+to+chagai}} On 20 December, Abdus Salam established the [[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology#Research divisions|Theoretical Physics Group]] (TPG) in [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|PAEC]] after calling two [[theoretical physicists]] working at the [[International Center for Theoretical Physics|ICTP]] to meet with Khan at the [[Quaid-e-Azam University]]. The TPG under [[Abdus Salam|Salam]] began calculating hidden physics and mathematics problems and seeking [[Method of fundamental solutions|solutions]] for [[fast neutron calculations]] as well as theoretically developing appropriate designs for the [[atomic bomb]]s. In 1973, [[Abdus Salam|Salam]] took over the additional work on [[fast neutron calculations]] working directly under the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|PAEC]]. One of the important acts was to call for a meeting for physical development of a bomb at his [[PINSTECH|Pinstech building]], inviting [[Mechanical engineering|mechanical engineer]] [[Muhammad Hafeez Qureshi|Hafeez Qureshi]] and [[Chemical engineering|chemical engineer]] dr. Zaman Shaikh from [[DESTO (Pakistan)|DESTO]].{{cite news|last1=Azam|first1=Rai Muhammad Saleh|authorlink1=Where Mountains Move: The Story of Chagai|title=Where Mountains Move: The Story of Chagai|url=http://nation.com.pk/|accessdate=21 January 2015|work=Special editorial work by Rai Muhammad Saleh Azam and published at the Natio|agency=The Nation|publisher=Pakistan Defence Journal, Rai|date=3 June 2003|archiveurl=http://pakdef.org/where-mountains-move-the-story-of-chagai/|archivedate=12 June 2000}} Attending with the [[Abdus Salam|Salam]] and [[Riazuddin (physicist)|Riazuddin]] of TPG, it was decided to established the secretive Directorate for Technical Development (DTD) which would conduct engineering calculations for the physical development to make the bomb. During the meeting the word "[[Atom bomb|''bomb'']]" was never used, but the participants fully understood what was being discussed. The next day, Salam, Riazuddin and Khan chaired a last meeting with [[Lieutenant-General]] Qamar Ali Mirza and the [[Engineer-in-Chief (Pakistan Army)|Engineer-in-Chief]] of the [[Corps of Engineers, Pakistan Army|Corps of Engineers]] to handle its part in atomic bomb project, with first starting the construction of the [[Metallurgical Laboratory (Wah)|Metallurgical Laboratory]] (Met Lab).{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=41–43}} Meanwhile, the DTD busied itself to developed the chemical [[explosive lens]]es, [[Tamper (nuclear weapon)|tampers]], a sub-critical sphere of fissile material could be squeezed into a smaller and denser form. The TPG worked under [[Abdus Salam|Salam]] until 1974; after Salam's departure, the TPG was instituted under [[Riazuddin (physicist)|Riazuddin]] directly reporting to Khan, and continued to develop new indigenous nuclear weapons designs which were tested in various cold tests by PAEC. In the months and initial years following Khan's taking over the atomic bomb project, the PAEC's corporate management entered into agreements with [[France]], [[Belgium]], [[Canada]], and [[West-Germany|Germany]] for the supply of a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant, a [[heavy water]] plant and a nuclear fuel fabrication plant, which were to be under IAEA safeguards.{{Citation | last =Causar Nyäzie | author-link =Kausar Niazi | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title =Last days of Prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto | place =Islamabad, Islamabad Capital Territory | publisher =Maulana Causar Nyazie and Sani Panwjap | series =1 | volume =1 | origyear =1994 |date=May 1994 | edition =1 | chapter =§9: The Reprocessing Plant—The Inside Story | chapterurl =https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:wzM8bvjZK3MJ:www.bhutto.org/Acrobat/Last%2520Dayf%2520of%2520Premier%2520Bhutto.pdf+Last+days+of+Premier+Bhutto&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjckwrTw4dvTbVQ2FEflsRU20aldSdvHTlXvKXEg4jkiZqdwZrD_yaOBO8SkqEM8Dv-f2TL8N6Tri_NNszXlQJ_35yornnzkagXTmrJvjakcy984S3LgbVKQUDXLgEm9WGwFCWf&sig=AHIEtbQ8JmT-OzGeBtHj-U1-gM8pY0SJPA | pages =55–56 | url =https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:wzM8bvjZK3MJ:www.bhutto.org/Acrobat/Last%2520Dayf%2520of%2520Premier%2520Bhutto.pdf+Last+days+of+Premier+Bhutto&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjckwrTw4dvTbVQ2FEflsRU20aldSdvHTlXvKXEg4jkiZqdwZrD_yaOBO8SkqEM8Dv-f2TL8N6Tri_NNszXlQJ_35yornnzkagXTmrJvjakcy984S3LgbVKQUDXLgEm9WGwFCWf&sig=AHIEtbQ8JmT-OzGeBtHj-U1-gM8pY0SJPA | id = | isbn =978-969-8500-00-9 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }} None of the agreements were made feasible and further abrogated by each states when India conducted its [[Smiling Buddha|surprise nuclear test]] in 1974 and Pakistan's stance on refusing the [[Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty]] (NPT). ===1971 war and atomic bomb project=== {{See also|Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program}} In 1972, the development efforts were directed to a [[plutonium]]-[[Implosion-type nuclear weapon|implosion type weapon]], called ''[[Kirana-I]]''.{{cite book|last=Rehman|first=Shahidur|title=Long Road to Chagai:§ Munir Ahmad Khan, an interview with author|year=1999|publisher=Shahid-ur-Rehman, 1999; Printwise Publications of Islamabad (§ Munir Ahmad Khan, an interview with author)|location=Islamabad, Oxford|isbn=978-969-8500-00-9|page=157|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sNMgAQAAIAAJ&q=Munir+Ahmad+Khan&dq=long+road+to+chagai}} On 18 May 1974, Khan was in [[Peshawar]] for laying the foundations of an agriculture center at [[Nuclear Institute for Food and Agriculture]] (NIFA), when India surprisingly conducted a [[Smiling Buddha|nuclear test]]; therefore, Khan cancelled the meeting despite [[civil engineer]] [[Farhatullah Babar]]'s recommendation and flew to Islamabad to hold talks with Zulfikar Bhutto. Farhatullah Babar has described Khan's response after Indian explosion: {{quote|text=The day (May 18, 1974) India immaturely exploded her device, Munir Khan was in Peshawar where he had laid the foundation of an agricultural center and had planned a press conference in the evening... When Munir Khan heard the news, he cancelled the press conference. I insisted to continue the conference as it was planned, Munir Khan refused and said: "You should not expect me to talk about potatoes and onions when the Indians are exploding a nuclear device close to our border....". |sign=[[Farhatullah Babar]], statement issued on 29th April 2005|source=}} As he returned to Islamabad, Khan wrote a lengthy and detailed paper titled "''India's nuclear explosion: Challenge and Response''", and published his paper in [[IAEA]] soon after. Sensing the political importance of the test, Khan launched the initiated [[Project-706|secret work]] on [[uranium enrichment]] under [[Sultan Bashiruddin Mahmood|Bashiruddin Mahmood]]. [[Khalil Qureshi]], a [[Physical chemistry|physical chemist]] joined the [[Project-706|uranium enrichment]] project in 1975, and did most of the calculations on [[Weapon-grade|military-grade]] uranium. In 1976, [[Metallurgical Engineering|metallurgist]] [[Abdul Qadeer Khan]] further collaborated with [[Sultan Bashiruddin Mahmood|Bashiruddin Mahmood]] and [[Khalil Qureshi]] on [[Project-706|uranium enrichment]] project. Technical difficulties and peer problems led to separation of [[Project-706|uranium enrichment]] project and put it under the [[Corps of Engineers, Pakistan Army|Corps of Engineers]] with dr. [[Abdul Qadeer Khan]] being its chief scientist. The [[Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction|atomic bomb project]] quickly transferred from civilian [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)|Ministry of Science]] to the [[Pakistan Military|military]]. By June 1976, the team of scientists and engineers under the physicist [[Ghulam Dastagir Allam|GD Allam]] began rotating the first experimental centrifuges at the [[PAF Base Chaklala|Air Force Science Research Laboratories]]. {{Rquote|right|"We were not just making the [[Atom bomb|bomb]], but building [[Science and technology in Pakistan|science and technology...]].|Munir Khan describing the atomic bomb efforts| }} In 1976, Khan tasked [[Ishfaq Ahmad]] and [[Ahsan Mubarak]] to scout for a suitable nuclear test site with the help from the [[Corps of Engineers, Pakistan Army|Corps of Engineers]] and [[Geological Survey of Pakistan]] (GSP). The team searched for a high scalar altitude graphite-mountain that would be suitable to take more than ~40[[kiloton|kn]] of [[nuclear force]] when the [[nuclear chain reaction|chain reaction]] from a uranium or plutonium-based nuclear device using lithium /or beryllium reflectors. The team completed the site selection and development work of the nuclear test sites at [[Chagai Hills|Chaghi]] and [[Kharan District|Kharan]] in Baluchistan by 1980. Meanwhile, the TPG completed the research on [[Fast neutron calculations]], [[hydrodynamics]], and the designing of the fission weapons by 1978 and by 1982–83, work on the bomb was completed by PAEC. The joint work of the various groups working in the Directorate of Technical Development and the Theoretical Physics Group in PAEC led to the first cold-test of a working atomic bomb on 11 March 1983, without the fissile material to prevent the [[nuclear fission]],"Pakistan Became a Nuclear State in 1983-Dr. Samar", The Nation,(Islamabad) 2 May 2003 Retrieved 6 August 2009.{{cite web|last=Nuclear files|title=Memoirs of Munir Ahmad Khan during the atomic bomb project|url=http://www.nuclearfiles.org/menu/key-issues/nuclear-weapons/issues/policy/pakistani-nuclear-policy/munir%20ahmad%20khan%27s%20speech.html|website=Munir Ahmad Khan|publisher=Nuclear files|accessdate=16 October 2012}} on a site that Munir Khan codenamed ''[[Kirana-I]]''. A test team headed by Ishfaq Ahmad, the test's preparation and calculations were oversaw by Khan; other invitees to witness the test included senior statesman that [[Ghulam Ishaq Khan]], and senior military officers including general [[Khalid Mahmud Arif|Khalid Arif]]. One of Khan's achievements is his technical leadership of the atomic bomb project, modelled on the ''[[Manhattan Project]]'' that prevented the exploitation and politicisation of the atomic bomb project into the hands of politicians, lawmakers, and the military officials. Khan focused on developing the atomic weapons and a diverse nuclear program, and regarded this clandestine atomic bomb project as building the science and technology for the country.{{cite book|last=Rehman|first=Shahid-ur|title=Long Road to Chagai Munir Ahmad Khan, an interview with author|year=1999|publisher=Munir Ahmad Khan's interview with Shahidur Rahman|location=ISlamabad|page=157}} The 1974 was a difficult year for Pakistan and it was anticipated that Pakistan would now have to face international embargoes and sanctions on acquisition of nuclear technology and equipment from supplier states.{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=52–59}} So a long-term effort was launched for the indigenous production of spare parts, equipment and components for the atom bomb and the energy project.{{Cite journal | last =M. Amjad Pervez PhD (Theoretical Physics) | first = | authorlink = | title =Heavy Manufacturing Facilities of Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission | journal =M. Amjad Pervez, the Nucleus | volume =42 | issue =1–2 | pages =1–4 | url =http://www.thenucleuspak.org.pk/nucleus/pdf%20Special%20Issue%20Nucleus%2042(1-4)/Heavy%20manufacturing%20facilities(ms-609).pdf | jstor = | issn = | doi = | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate =3 June 2011 }} To oversaw the uranium enrichment project, a Uranium Coordination Board (UCB) was set up to manage and supervise the enrichment project with Khan remained the scientific director of atomic bomb project; it had [[Ghulam Ishaq Khan]], [[A G N Kazi|AGN Kazi]], [[Agha Shahi]] its members.{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=60–61}} The UCB was eventually taken over by the [[Pakistan Military|military]] with [[Major-General]] [[Zahid Ali Akbar]] becoming its director with Abdul Qadeer Khan was made its chief scientist.{{cite book|last=Rehman|first=Shahidur|title=Long Road to Chagai:§ Dr. A.Q. Khan: Nothing Succeed like Success|year=1999|publisher=Shahid-ur-Rehman, 1999; Printwise Publications of Islamabad|location=Islamabad, Oxford|isbn=978-969-8500-00-9|page=157|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sNMgAQAAIAAJ&q=Munir+Ahmad+Khan&dq=long+road+to+chagai}} During a visit to PAEC's [[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science and Technology]] (PINSTECH), in November 1986, the President of Pakistan, General Zia-ul-Haq praised the work being carried out in PAEC. He wrote in the visitor's book: {{cquote|It has been a matter of great pride and satisfaction to see what all is going on in (Pakistan) Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC). It was heartening to see the progress that has taken place..... I congratulate Munir and his associates for all that they have done.... The People of Pakistan are proud of their achievements and pray for their success in the future.{{cite web | title =PINSTECH Silver Jubilee Technical Report- 1965–1990 | url = | year =1990 | accessdate = }} }} ===Plutonium test: Chagai-II=== {{Main|Kirana-I|Chagai-II}} From the outset, Khan focused on the indigenous development of a plutonium program as part of the fuel cycle. Despite many difficulties, Khan and PAEC successfully developed and managed the plutonium infrastructure. Khan lobbied and enlightened the importance of plutonium-tritium device and countered the scientific opposition that was led by fellow scientist [[Abdul Qadeer Khan]], who opposed the plutonium route and favoured the uranium atomic bomb. Khan concentrated the development efforts on [[plutonium]] [[Implosion-type nuclear weapon|implosion-type fission]] device, in a single group of TPG, which became to known as ''Chagai-II''. Khan countered and later abandoned the developmental efforts on [[uranium]] [[gun-type fission weapon]], when on developing the theoretical design, a problem was discovered by ''TPG'' who put efforts to work with Qadeer Khan on gun-type in 1976. The gun-type fission weapon is a simpler design that only had to work with uranium-235 but a possibility of weapon's chain reaction to reach the limit of fizzle level was identified; therefore, the ''TPG'' and Khan abandoned the gun design in favour of an implosion-type weapon. In 1983, a milestone was done when a joint work of scientists produced the artificial non-nuclear fission reaction at Kirana Atomic Tests Site (KATS) where the reactor-grade plutonium was used to defer the weapon to go fission. In May 1998, the success of plutonium bomb was proved when it was reported that PAEC conducted a test of a powerful plutonium device, ''[[Chagai-II]]'', to artificially produced the nuclear fission, and this plutonium device had the largest yield of all the uranium bombs. In 1999, Khan described the large scientific efforts and PAEC's contribution in heading up and building Pakistan's atomic bomb project, as he stated: {{quote|text=In 1979–80, the PAEC completed the iron-steel tunnels in Chagai region. On March 11, 1983, we successfully conducted [our] (cold) [[Atomic test|test]] of a working [[atomic bomb]]. That evening, I went to General Zia with the news that Pakistan was now ready to make an [[atomic bomb]]. We conducted this cold test long before the fissile material was available for actual test. We were ahead of others.....|sign=Munir Ahmad Khan, Statement giving to news media in 1999|source=source.}} ===Arms race and diplomacy with India=== {{See also|Operation Opera|Operation Brasstacks}} By 1979, the [[Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program|atomic bomb program]] was no longer a secret to the world, especially India who was alarmed by the success of this crash program.{{harvnb|Rahman|1998|pp=77–80}} Aggressive measures were taken towards modernizing the [[Indian nuclear programme]] in parallel to advancing the [[Indian Space Research Organisation|Indian space programme]]. As a military policy maker, Khan initiated clandestine defence projects in the [[Pakistani military|military]], including lobbying for [[Integrated Missile Research and Development Programme|missile program]] and other strategic projects.{{harvnb|Khan|2012|pp=231–235}} Witnessing successful launch of the Indian [[Indian Space Research Organisation|ISRO]]'s [[Rohini (satellite)#RS-D1|''Rohini'']] in 1980 through its own [[Satellite Launch Vehicle|SLV]], Khan lobbied for elevation of the [[Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission|Space Research Commission]], securing funds for the space projects. Helping to appoint [[Salim Mehmud]] as chairman of [[Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission|Space Research Commission]], Khan secured fundings for the development of country's first, the [[Badr-1|Moon-I]], which was eventually launched in 1990. Development on [[Unguided bomb|unguided]]-[[gravity bomb]]s, [[Tactical nuclear weapon|tactical weapons]] for [[Pakistan Air Force|PAF]]'s [[Air Force Strategic Command (Pakistan)|Air Force Strategic Command]] were watchfully completed under Khan's guidance.{{harvnb|Khan|2012|pp=207–252}} The air force engineers successfully installed the system in PAF's [[Mirage 5|Mirage-5]], [[Q-5 Fantan|A-5]], and the [[F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16s]] as the [[F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16s]] successfully performed and mastered the low-level laydown aerial techniques, [[Free-fall bomb|conventional free-fall drop]]—a method to drop gravitated nuclear bomb through fighter jets.{{harvnb|Khan|2012|pp=232–240}} At international conferences, Khan criticised India for its nuclear programme, and in 1999, Khan defended Pakistan's non-nuclear weapon policy as well as the nuclear tests when he summed up his thoughts: {{quote|text=In 1972, we (Pakistan) made a [nuclear policy] statement... that [Pakistan] wanted a [[nuclear-free zone]] in [[South Asia]] (so) that the [[Natural resource|resources]] in the [[Indian subcontinent|sub-continent]] could be focused on solving problems of poverty and deprivation of [one] billion people in this region of the world. But India did not listen to (Pakistan).... Now that we have responded to India's nuclear aggression, (Pakistan) hope that they will listen to us...|sign=Munir Ahmad Khan, stating his views on ''[[Operation Shakti]]'' in 1999|source={{cite web|last1=Khan|first1=Munir Ahmad|title=Chaghi Medal Award Ceremony|url=http://pakdef.org/mr-munir-ahmad-khans-speech-delivered-on-march-20-1999-at-pinstech-auditorium-chaghi-medal-award-ceremony/|publisher=Munir Ahmad Khan’s Speech on Chaghi Medal Award Ceremony|accessdate=21 January 2015}}}} In 1981, Israel's [[Operation Opera]] attacked [[Iraq]]'s [[Osirak Nuclear Reactor]]. Great panic was caused in Pakistan and hectic discussions now began to take place between ministries of [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)|Science]], [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Foreign Affairs]], and [[Ministry of Defence (Pakistan)|Defence]] over this issue each day. In 1983, the [[Inter-Services Intelligence|ISI]] gained advance knowledge on similar plans on attacking Pakistan's facilities, namely [[Kahuta Research Laboratories|KRL]] and [[PINSTECH|Pinstech]]. Although the [[Pakistan Air Force]] was high alert, the [[Pakistan Government|Pakistan government]] leaked prior information to Khan who was at the [[IAEA]] to mediate the tensions in the region. At that time, Khan was attending the [[IAEA]]'s [[General Conference (United Nations)|General Conference]] on [[nuclear safety]] issues and received a secret-coded message, through [[:Category:Ambassadors of Pakistan to Austria|Ambassador of Pakistan to Austria]] [[Abdul Sattar (diplomat)|Abdul Sattar]], from the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Foreign ministry]]. Khan invited dr. [[Raja Ramana]] of [[Atomic Energy Commission of India|Indian Atomic Energy Commission]] to the dinner at the [[Hotel Imperial (Vienna, Austria)|Imperial Hotel]] at [[Vienna]] to confirm the veracity of the knowledge. Reportedly, Khan told [[Raja Ramana]] that "any attack on Pakistan's [nuclear] facilities would trigger a possible Pakistan [[Second strike|retaliatory strike]] on Indian nuclear facilities at Trombay, which will result in the release of radioactivity causing a major disaster. Upon returning, [[Raja Ramana]] held leaks information to [[Indian government]] and convened Khan's message to [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] [[Indira Gandhi]] about Pakistan's [[Second strike|retaliatory strikes]]. Plans were postponed and the matter subsequently shelved. In 1988, the governments of [[Government of India|India]] and [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan]] reached to the [[Agreement Between India and Pakistan on the Prohibition of Attack against Nuclear Installations and Facilities|concessions for agreeing]] that both countries would not attack each other's nuclear facilities."George Perkovich,''India's Nuclear Bomb: The Impact on Global Proliferation'' (Berkeley, Los Angeles, and London: University of California Press, 1999), p. 241.http://www.nti.org/e_research/profiles/India/Nuclear/chronology_1983.html." ===Government work and advocacy=== {{Main|Nuclear energy in Pakistan}} Since 1975, Khan had been lobbying for resolving [[energy crises]] by depending on [[Nuclear power in Pakistan|nuclear power]] sources, and had been in direct negotiation with [[United Kingdom|British]] [[British Nuclear Fuels plc|BNFL]] and [[France|French]] [[Commissariat à l'énergie atomique|CEA]] for a [[Nuclear reprocessing|reprocessing plant]] at [[Chashma, Pakistan|Chashma]]. Despite each facilities were put under the [[IAEA safeguards|IAEA inspections]], none of the plans were feasible due to [[United States|U.S.]] objections. By the time, the [[Commissariat à l'énergie atomique|CEA]] cancelled the project, the [[Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|PAEC]] had acquired 95% of detailed plans [[Nuclear reprocessing|reprocessing plant]] which resulted in local constructions of the [[Pakistan Atomic Research Reactor#PARR-III Reactor (New-Labs)|New Labs]]. By the 1980s, Khan had been serving as the [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)#Science Advisors|Science Advisor]] playing integral role in implementing policies on science. In 1985, Khan lobbied for another plutonium production plant at Khushab, which is known as [[Khushab Nuclear Complex|Khushab Complex]]; and gained the approval of [[Khushab Nuclear Complex|Khushab I]]— a multipurpose heavy water plant, and a tritium production complex. In 1987, Khan had been lobbying for acquiring [[Nuclear power plant|nuclear plants]] from [[People's Republic of China|China]] which resulted in constructing the [[Chashma Nuclear Power Plant|commercial nuclear power plant]] in [[Chashma, Pakistan|Chashma]]. Acting as [[Minister of State]], he assisted [[Foreign minister of pakistan|Foreign minister]] [[Sahabzada Yaqub Khan|Yaqub Khan]] in [[Beijing]] where he signed the agreement on behalf of Pakistan with [[Premier of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Premier]] [[Li Peng]]. This accord opened the way for Pakistan to receive Chinese assistance in setting up four 300[[Megawatt|MWe]] commercial nuclear power plants under [[IAEA]] safeguards at Chashma. Therefore, PAEC reached an agreement with China in November 1989 for the supply of 300[[Megawatt|MWe]] [[Chashma Nuclear Power Plant#Unit 1|CHASHNUPP-I]] commercial nuclear power plant.{{Cite news | last = | first = | title =Nuclear Developments: Pakistani Official On Reactor | newspaper =[[Xinhua News Agency]] | location =Beijin, People's Republic of China | page =1 | publisher =[[Xinhua News Agency]] | date = 20 November 1989 | url = | accessdate =}} In February 1990, [[President of France|French President]] [[François Mitterrand|Mitterrand]] visited Pakistan and announced that France had agreed to supply 900[[Megawatt|MWe]] commercial nuclear power reactor to Pakistan which was to be under [[IAEA]] safeguards.{{Cite news | last = | first = | title =Pakistan: Details On Bhutto-Mitterrand News Conference | newspaper =Islamabad Domestic Service | location =Islamabad, Islamabad Capital Territory | page =1 | publisher =[[Xinhua News Agency]] | date =21 February 1990 | url = | accessdate =}} Shortly afterward, Khan stated that the signing of civil nuclear cooperation agreements with China and France had broken a fifteen-year virtual embargo by western states on the supply of nuclear power plants to Pakistan.{{Cite news | last = | first = | title =Nuclear developments: Munir Assures Safety In Nuclear Radiation Utilization | newspaper =[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn Newspaper]] | location =Karachi, Sindh Province of Pakistan | page =12 | publisher =[[Dawn Group of Newspapers]] | date = 15 May 1990 | url = | accessdate =}} In 1990, Khan entered in negotiations with [[France]] but remained unsuccessful to acquire commercial nuclear plant from [[France]] when [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Benazir Bhutto]] was dismissed from the government. ==Death== On 22 April 1999, Khan died following complications from heart surgery at the age of 72 in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]]. He is survived by his wife, Thera, three children and four grandchildren.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/24/world/munir-a-khan-72-managed-nuclear-program-in-pakistan.html|title=Munir A. Khan, 72, Managed Nuclear Program in Pakistan|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|author-first=Malcolm W.|author-last=Browne|date=24 April 1999|accessdate=9 September 2017}} ==Legacy== {{Main|Chagai-I|Chagai-II}} When Abdus Salam was ejected from his position in 1974, Khan symbolised of many scientists thinking they could control how other peers would use their research. During the timeline of atomic bomb project, Khan was seen as a symbol of both moral responsibility of scientists, and to the contribution to the rise of Pakistan's science while preventing the politicisation of the project. Popular depiction of Khan's views on nuclear proliferation as a confrontation between right-wing militarists (symbolised by Abdul Qadeer Khan) and left-wing intellectuals (symbolised by Munir Khan) over the moral question of weapons of mass destruction.{{cite book|title=Organizational Cultures and the Management of Nuclear Technology Political and Military Sociology|date=2012|publisher=Transaction Pub|isbn=978-1-4128-4945-6|pages=50–150|editor=Karthika Susikumar|format=google books|chapter=Odyssey of Pakistan's largest scientific endeavors towards the building of atomic bombs|url=https://books.google.com/?id=n8SZlczNkUkC&pg=PA71&dq=GD+Alam#v=onepage&q=GD%20Alam&f=false}} Babar portrayed Khan as "tragic fate but consciously genius", and also dubbed him as "Nuclear Sage" of Pakistan. In 1999, Khan staunchly backed his country's nuclear technology project, as he puts it: {{quote|text=The genius of Pakistan (since its establishment in 1947) is her science and her scientists and engineers. [[Politicization of science|Mixing]] [[science]] with [[politics]] is very, very dangerous. This will contaminate the politics which is never clean, with radioactivity, and it will [[Deutsche Physik|destroy]] the science as we witnessed in [[Nazi Germany|[Nazi] Germany]] in 1940s when their [[German nuclear energy project|atomic bomb project]] was politicised for [absolute] political gain. Without a comprehensive [nuclear and political] policy, things do not work, and no country can go developed its nuclear project without having some kind of framework in which to operate. We had to develop a political strategy to launch our project without arousing great deal of suspicion and opposition at the international level, because no body in the world wanted to see Pakistan to become nuclear power. But we had no choice [as mentioned by Bhutto in 1965]. I can tell you...... that it is not only the Western countries; we were wronged by some of the countries who we regard as our friends. It is not because the people in those countries oppose this project, but the governments felt, the rulers felt that Pakistan would become too strong. |sign=Munir Ahmad Khan, statement on May 1999|source=source{{failed verification|date=July 2015}} }} As a scientist, Khan is remembered by his peers as brilliant researcher and engaging teacher, the founder of nuclear engineering in Pakistan. In spite of his academic discipline, Khan had diverse interests in nuclear physics and theoretical physics where he researched and worked under his mentor Abdus Salam on many problems arising theoretical physics and the nuclear engineering. An award, Munir Ahmad Khan Gold Medal, is named after him at [[Pakistan Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences|Institute of Engineering and Applied Sciences]]. After years of urging of many of Khan's colleagues in PAEC and his powerful [[Pakistan Peoples Party|political friends]] who had ascended to power in the government, President [[Asif Ali Zardari]] bestowed and honored Khan with the prestigious and highest civilian state award, [[Nishan-e-Imtiaz]] in 2012 as a gesture of political rehabilitation.{{cite news|title=Civilian awards: Presidency issues list of 192 recipients|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/421617/civilian-awards-presidency-issues-list-of-192-recipients/|accessdate=29 Dec 2016|newspaper=The Tribune Express newspaper|date=13 August 2012|author=Staff Report|agency=The Tribune Express|page=1}} As military and public policy maker, Khan was a [[Technocracy (bureaucratic)|technocrat]] leader in a shift between [[Military funding of science|science and military]], and the emergence of the concept of the big science in Pakistan. During the Cold war, scientists became involved in military research on unprecedented degree, because of the threat [[communism]] and Indian integration posed to Pakistan, scientists volunteered in great numbers both for technological and organizational assistance to Pakistan's efforts that resulted in powerful tools such as [[laser rangefinder]], the proximity fuse and operations research. As a cultured, intellectual, nuclear engineer who became a disciplined military organiser, Khan represented the shift away from the idea that scientists had their "head in the clouds" and that knowledge on such previously esoteric subjects as the composition of the atomic nucleus had no "real-world" applications .http://www.nuclearfiles.org/menu/key-issues/nuclear-weapons/issues/policy/pakistani-nuclear-policy/munir%20ahmad%20khan's%20speech.html ==Quotes by Khan== * ''"We have to understand that nuclear weapons are not a play thing to be bandied publicly. They have to be treated with respect and responsibility. While they can destroy the enemy, they can also invite self destruction."'' * ''"While we were building capabilities in the nuclear fuel cycle, we started in parallel the design of a nuclear device, with its trigger mechanism, physics calculations, production of metal, making precision mechanical components, high-speed electronics, diagnostics, and testing facilities. For each one of them, we established different laboratories".'' * ''"Many sources were tapped after the decision to go nuclear. We were simultaneously working on 20 labs and projects under the administrative control of PAEC, every one the size of Khan Research Laboratories."'' * ''"On 11 March 1983, we successfully conducted the first cold test of a working nuclear device. That evening, I went to General Zia with the news that Pakistan was now ready to make a nuclear device."'' ==State Honors== {{Col-begin}}{{Col-break|width=50%}} * [[Nishan-e-Imtiaz]] (2012; Posthumous) * [[Hilal-e-Imtiaz]] (1989) *[[Gold medal]], [[Pakistan Academy of Sciences|PAS]] (1992) *[[Fulbright Award]] (1951) * [[Honors student|Roll of Honor]], [[Government College University, Lahore|GCU]] (1946) {{Col-break}} * Fellowship, [[Pakistan Nuclear Society|PNS]] (1999) * Fellowship, [[American Nuclear Society|ANS]] (1999) * Fellowship, Pakistan Institute of Electrical Engineers (1992) * Fellowship, [[Sigma Xi]] Society (1953–1956) * [[Rotary International]] [[Fellow]]ship (1951) {{Col-end}} ==See also== Some more Pakistani nuclear scientists: * [[Abdul Qadeer Khan]] * [[Abdus Salam]] * [[Ishfaq Ahmad]] * [[Samar Mubarakmand]] * [[Riazuddin (physicist)]] ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|group=nb}} ;Citations {{Reflist|30em}} ===Anecdotes=== {{Col-begin}}{{Col-break|width=50%}} * [http://www.salaam.co.uk/knowledge/biography/viewentry.php?id=1221. Munir Ahmed Khan gold medal] * [http://www.minersoc.org/pages/Archive-MM/Volume_47/47-344-391.pdf Mineral Research Laboratories] {{Col-end}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin|30em}} *{{Cite book |last=Rahman |first=Shahid |contribution=§Munir Ahmad Khan: An interview with Author; §Theoretical Physics Group, a "Cue" from Manhattan Project"?; §Pakistan nuclear technology project: from Pakistan's Theoretical Physics to the making of the bomb; §Operation Sun Rise— Army and the militarized atomic science |pages=27–157|editor-last=Rahman |editor-first=Shahid|editor2-last= |editor2-first= |title=Long Road to Chagai|location=Islamabad, Pakistan|year=1998|isbn=978-969-8500-00-9 |publisher=Printwise publication|oclc=|ref=harv}} *{{Cite book |last= Malik |first=Hafeez |contribution=§Munir Ahmad Khan: Technical Director of Atomic Bomb Project |pages=149–209pp|editor-last=Malik|editor-first=Hafeez|editor2-last= |editor2-first= |title=Pakistan: founder's aspirations and today's realities|location=University of Michigan|year=1998|isbn=978-0-19-579333-8 |publisher=Oxford University Press, 2001|oclc=|ref=harv}} *{{Cite book |last=Sardar |first=Zia-uddin |contribution=§Munir Ahmad Khan: Pakistan's nuclear supremo |pages=402–406pp|editor-last=Malik|editor-first=Hafeez|editor2-last= |editor2-first= |title=New Scientist|location=London, United Kingdom|date=12 February 1998|issn=0262-4079 |publisher=Oxford University Press, 1981|oclc=|ref=harv}} *{{Cite book |last=Babar |first=Farhatullah |contribution=§Golden years of Pakistan: a journey from the 1960s Pakistan school of Theoretical physics to the 1998 year of testings |pages=100–150|editor-last=Babar|editor-first=Farhatulla|editor2-last= |editor2-first= |title=The Nuclear Sage|location=Karachi, Sindh Province|date=17 February 2000|publisher=Pakistan Science Publishing co. {{distinguish|Reverse racism}} '''New racism''' is a term coined in 1981 by [[Marxism|Marxist]] professor of film [[Martin Barker]], in the context of the ideologies supporting [[Margaret Thatcher]]'s rise in the [[United Kingdom|UK]], to refer to what he believed was [[racist]] [[public discourse]] depicting [[immigrants]] as a threat.<ref name="Chin09"/><ref name="Cole97p12"/> New racism can be described as "more indirect, more subtle, more procedural, more ostensibly nonracial".<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 2111369|title = The New Racism|last = Pettigrew|first = |date = 1991|journal = American Journal of Political Science|doi = 10.2307/2111369|pmid = |volume=35|pages=423}}</ref> New racism suggests to have some sort of new strength because it does not appear to be [[racism]]. New racism relies more heavily on manipulation of ideas within [[mass media]] and to reproduce and disseminate the ideologies needed to justify racism. These new techniques present [[Hegemony|hegemonic ideologies]] that claim that racism is over.<ref name="Collins 2004 1">{{Cite book|title = Black Sexual Politics|last = Collins|first = Patricia Hill|publisher = Routledge New York|year = 2004|isbn = |location = New York|pages = 1}}</ref> It is also transnational; one can now have racial inequality that does not appear to be regulated by the state to the same degree. Globalization, [[Transnationalism|trans-nationalism]], and the growth of hegemonic ideologies within mass media provide the context for a new racism that has catalyzed changes within African, Black American and African-Diasporic societies.<ref name="Collins 2004 1"/>
==1980s wave of anti-immigrant sentiment== From the 1980s, the increase in [[globalization|global inequalities]] between poor and rich countries led to significant immigration flows to Europe, even in those less developed European countries that until the 1970s were more a source of emigration.
A new wave of [[Opposition to immigration|anti-immigrant]] sentiment had started to emerge in the 1970s, most significantly with UK's [[National Front (United Kingdom)|National Front]]; in the early such sentiments gained significant support, most prominently with the electoral success of [[Jean-Marie Le Pen]]'s [[Front National (France)|Front National]] French party, which gained 10% of the vote in the [[1984 European elections]].<ref name="Cole97p12"/> Le Pen's success will serve as a model for many parties and movements that will emulate him all over Europe.<ref name="Cole97p12"/><ref>Dancygier, Rafaela M. (2010) [https://books.google.com/books?id=vTRzzVMzhScC ''Immigration and Conflict in Europe''], p.5 quote: "The far-right ''Front National'' has served as a model to many anti-immigrant movements in Europe."</ref>
Many scholars have called this new anti-immigrant sentiments, and the ideologies alimenting it, a new form of racism,<ref name="Cole97p12"/> and the label "new racism" has been particularly influential.<ref name="Chin09">Chin (2009) pp.13, 92, 178-9, 241</ref> These scholars argued that the new racism had to cope with the mainstream official repudiation of racism, [[Fascism]] and [[Nazism]], and as a consequence substituted the rhetoric of race and biology with that of [[cultural identity]].<ref name="Cole97p12"/>
These sentiments were first expressed by marginal parties, but as they increased their support by attracting votes from mainstream parties, the leaders of such parties, Margaret Thatcher<ref name="Chin09"/> and [[Bettino Craxi]]<ref>Ginsborg (2003) pp.62, 176</ref><ref>Guild and Minderhoud (2006) p.173</ref> started to embrace some of the same anti-immigrant ideologies.<ref name="Cole97p12">Cole, Jeffrey (1997) [https://books.google.com/books?id=kB3Nqg0ZL8oC ''The new racism in Europe: a Sicilian ethnography''], p.11-2</ref>
==See also== *[[2005 civil unrest in France]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *{{Cite book |title=After the Nazi racial state: difference and democracy in Germany and Europe |first=Rita C-K |last=Chin |year=2009 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tqlrRJHwjKoC&pg=PA92 |ref=harv}} *Guild, Elspeth and Minderhoud, Paul (2006) [https://books.google.com/books?id=1uCrJ8ykkOMC ''Immigration and criminal law in the European Union: the legal measures and social consequences of criminal law in member states on trafficking and smuggling in human beings''] *Ginsborg, Paul (2003) ''Italy and its discontents: family, civil society, state, 1980-2001'' *Romm, Norma RA (2010) ''New Racism: Revisiting Researcher Accountabilities''[https://www.springer.com/978-90-481-8727-0] *Coates, Rodney (2011)[ed] ''Covert Racism: Theories, Institutions, and Experiences''
